quoteLast: when Susi heard Majwara's step once more. "Come to Bwana, I am afraid; I don't know if he is alive." The lad's evident alarm made Susi run to arouse Chumah, Chowperé, Matthew, and Muanyaséré, and the six men went immediately to the hut.
title:
The Last Journals of David Livingstone, in Central Africa, from 1865 to His Death, Volume II (of  2), 1869-1873
Continued By A Narrative Of His Last Moments And Sufferings, Obtained From His Faithful Servants Chuma And Susi
author: Livingstone, David, 1813-1873; Waller, Horace, 1833-1896 [Editor]

quoteFirst: --The temperature of blood in the human body is normally about 98.6° Fahrenheit when tested under the tongue by a thermometer, although the temperature drops almost two degrees after we have gone to sleep at night. It is highest about 5 P.M. and lowest
quoteLast: In fevers, the temperature of the body sometimes rises to 107°; but unless this temperature is soon reduced, death follows. Any considerable drop in temperature below the normal also means death.
title: A Civic Biology, Presented in Problems
author: Hunter, George W. (George William), 1873-1948

quoteLast: the President of the United States landed on the Mammouth Building in New York and was taken down in the elevator to the 110th floor to Supreme Commander Gordon's office. He found Colonel Edna Kennelworth sentinel at the door.

quoteFirst: When we left Bellagio, the two Misses Hawker, often our companions in Rome, accompanied us. We ascended the Splugen from Chiavenna in pitch darkness, till,
quoteLast: , the diligence entered upon the snow cuttings, and we proceeded for some time between walls of snow, often fifteen feet high. At last we stopped altogether, and in a spot where there was no refuge whatever from the ferocious ice-laden wind.
title: The Story of My Life, volumes 1-3
author: Hare, Augustus J. C. (Augustus John Cuthbert), 1834-1903

quoteFirst: He said he had, and that these sounds were just like those of a battle.  An interval of quiet then ensued, when again,
quoteLast: , arose other similar explosions, but I still remained in doubt whether the enemy was engaged in blowing up his own magazines, or whether General Slocum had not felt forward, and become engaged in a real battle.

quoteFirst: The type really varies at Tiflis according to the season of the year. In June--as in the mean equality from the whole year--there is a well marked double period; there is a principal minimum at 2 p.m. and a secondary one
quoteLast: ; a principal maximum about 9 a.m. and a secondary one about 6 p.m. In December, however, only a single period is recognizable, with a minimum about 8 a.m. and a maximum about 7 p.m. The type of diurnal inequality seen at the Cape of Good Hope does not differ much from that seen at Batavia. Only a single period is clearly shown.
title:
Encyclopaedia Britannica, 11th Edition, "McKinley, William" to "Magnetism, Terrestrial"
Volume 17, Slice 3

quoteFirst: _August 20th._--We continued an easterly course, and about noon had come in sight of False Pulo Ubi.
quoteLast: of the 21st, we passed the Island of Pulo Ubi, and towards evening, the barren islands called the Two Brothers. The latter are abrupt, precipitous, and naked rocks, covered with myriads of a species of Sterna.
title: The Mission to Siam, and Hué, the Capital of Cochin China, in the Years 1821-2

quoteFirst: The men had a drop of rum when we got back, and it was
quoteLast: when I crawled into my flea bag. A family of beetles played, “Come and sit on my chair” across my toes, and an old brown rat wanted to keep me company.
title: A Soldier's Diary
author: Scott, Ralph

quoteFirst: But before the torch had been put to a single building by Sherman's order, the smouldering fires set by Hampton were rekindled by the wind and communicated to the buildings around. About dark the flames began to spread, and were soon beyond the control of the brigade on duty in the town. An entire division was now brought in, but it was found impossible to check the conflagration, which by midnight had become quite unmanageable. It raged till
quoteLast: on the 18th, when the wind subsided, and the flames were got under control. … Beauregard, meanwhile, and the rebel cavalry, had retreated upon Charlotte, in North Carolina, due north from Columbia; and on the 20th and 21st Sherman followed as far as Winnsboro.
title: History for ready reference, Volumes 1 to 5
author: Larned, J. N. (Josephus Nelson), 1836-1913

quoteFirst: It was fine to see them falling on the plain at every volley. We ceased firing on the 10th,
title: Dixmude: The epic of the French marines (October 17-November 10, 1914)

quoteFirst: A brisk breeze of wind prevailed, and the weather was clear. The boats were, therefore, manned and sent in pursuit. After a chase of about five hours, the harpooner, commanding a boat, who, with another in company, had rowed out of sight of the ship, struck one of the whales. This was
quoteLast: , of the 29th. The captain, supposing from the long absence of the two most distant boats that a fish had been struck, directed the course of the ship towards the place where he had last seen them, and about eight A.M. he got sight of a boat which displayed the signal for being _fast_.
title: The northern whale-fishery
author: Scoresby, William, 1789-1857

quoteFirst: The mattress proved to be so tightly packed that it was easier, on the whole, to lie awake under it than to sleep on the top of it, and less painful.
quoteLast: one of the guides incautiously moved his head, and having thus disturbed his equilibrium fell heavily on to the floor. Thereupon he woke up and said it was time to start.
title: Above the Snow Line: Mountaineering Sketches Between 1870 and 1880
author: Dent, C. T. (Clinton Thomas), 1850-1912; Whymper, Edward, 1840-1911 [Engraver]; Macquoid, Percy, -1925 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The prisoners were sent from the shore with a boat load of ballast and slept on board the vessel. Two of them were called up at
quoteLast: to bale the boat out, and Jones asked William Harper, one of the sailors, if he could navigate? Harper replied "Yes, if I had a slate and pencil." No notice was taken of this incident at the time, but afterwards it was deemed to have been an indication that a conspiracy to seize the vessel had been formed among the prisoners.
title: History of the Australian Bushrangers
author: Boxall, George, 1836-1918

quoteLast: the wind changed, and we were able to use sail, which steadied the vessel, besides assisting her progress. I went on deck at nine, found the Mediterranean more like my 'Caire' experience, and was told that we should probably be at Grao by twelve....
